official-title.#text:
To provide for medical neutrality and to establish
		  accountability for violations of the principle of medical neutrality, and for
		  other purposes.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on the

, for a period
			 to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of
			 such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee
			 concerned

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text:
International humanitarian law codifies the
			 principle of medical neutrality in the Geneva Conventions, to which the United
			 States is a signatory, during times of national or international armed
			 conflict, which offer special protections to medical facilities and personnel.
			 These provisions recognize ambulances, hospitals, hospital ships, the personnel
			 serving in ambulances and hospitals, citizens who assist the wounded as neutral
			 and protected during conflict.

The Geneva
			 Conventions specify that the wounded and sick shall receive adequate care, be
			 protected from ill-treatment, and be protected from discrimination, and that
			 emblems such as the red cross and red crescent are recognized as protective
			 emblems in conflict. Many parts of the Geneva Conventions have been declared by
			 the International Committee on the Red Cross (ICRC) to be customary
			 international humanitarian law.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
affirms its
			 support of participants of peaceful demonstrations around the world, as part of
			 the United States support for freedom of assembly as enshrined in the United
			 States Constitution. The United States takes particular umbrage at countries
			 that harm or endanger medical professionals during times of unrest.

text.#text: In this Act:
The term

; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Appropriations of the Senate

text.#text: the

Until such time as there is a binding, internationally
			 recognized definition of the term

the protection of
			 unhindered access of the sick and injured to nondiscriminatory medical care and
			 treatment; and

the understanding
			 that all medical professionals are required to treat in a nondiscriminatory
			 manner any individual in need of care, and the responsibility of governments
			 not to interfere with such professional duty.

quote.#tail:
includes government-sanctioned actions, and actions which
			 are not authorized by a government policy but are not independently
			 investigated, including—

text.#text: The term

wanton destruction
			 of medical supplies, facilities, records, or transportation services;

willful
			 obstruction of medical ethics as specified in the World Medical Association’s
			 International Code of Medical Ethics, including preventing medical
			 professionals from administering ethical medical care to individuals in
			 need;

arbitrary arrest
			 or detention of health care service providers or individuals seeking medical
			 care.

Nothing in this
			 Act shall be construed to prevent or interfere with legitimate law enforcement
			 objectives conducted in accordance with recognized international human rights
			 norms and legal standards.

It shall be the policy
			 of the United States to—

consider the protection of medical
			 neutrality a policy priority of the United States as an integral part of the
			 defense of recognized international human rights law and international
			 humanitarian law;

use its voice,
			 vote, and influence in international fora to further define and codify the
			 principle of medical neutrality and to establish accountability for violations
			 of the principle of medical neutrality; and

use its voice, vote, and influence at the
			 United Nations Human Rights Council to create and appoint a Special Rapporteur
			 on the Protection and Promotion of Medical Neutrality.
